## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>. When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. 

This particular R Markdown document describes a gap analysis of how well point counts collated by the Boreal Avian Modelling Project (BAM) in Alberta are represented within different combinations of Natural Subregion, Stand Type, Age Class, and Timber Productivity Rating outlined in the risk matrix (v. 3) of incidental take by forestry operations, created by FORSITE for FRIAA (the Forestry Resource Inventory Association of Alberta). 

The first version of the gap analysis in May described the number of point counts occurring in each ForestID combination of subregion, stand type, age class, and timber productivity, the cumulative area of each ForestID combination, and relative sampling effort (points/10000 hectares) in each ForestID combination. Relative sampling effort enabled us to identify ForestID's, and combinations of subregion, stand type, age class, and/or timber productivity rating that have few or no point counts, thus could benefit the BAM database by contributing future point count samples.  

A new version of the gap analysis was done in July when missing observations from the Central Mixedwood Subregion were detected, and then examples of one-pagers tailored to specific Forestry Management Units were generated.

The most recent version of this analysis was run in September, and includes the creation of an AlbertaMastermatrix containing observations of cumulative area, subregion, stand, age-class, and timber productivity rating for each ForestID, and a separate list of risk matrix ranks for each ForestID. 

The first part of creating the risk matrix is done in ArcGIS. For some reason, I can't easily combine MOD1YR or ORIGINYR from the detailed AVI geodatabase, so the age-structure calculated here is as of 2017. Probably not an issue, just that the age structure as of 2017 is different from what would have been present when surveys were actually being done.
1. Calculate age of stand during survey using age2017 - (2017-YEAR). Some values will be negative
because stand age assessed in 2017 is calculated differently (just based on age2017)
than it was in the point counts.

## Step 1. Load data into R
The risk matrix AVI attribute table has to be exported as a series of CSV files because it is too large (6120960 rows) for a single CSV file (limit ~1 million rows) to contain all of the attribute table. I will then combine several separate CSV files after reading them into R, using rbind(). Before combining the separate read-in files with rbind(), I made sure that the columns and column names in each .csv file were identical. I also made sure that there were no duplicate observations (i.e.unique=nrow) and that the total number of observations after rbinding the CSV files was 6120960 observations.

```{r load, echo=FALSE}
riskmatrixAVI1<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/GISfiles/May17RiskMatrixV3_SubrCM_AlpacAVI.600Kplus.csv", header=TRUE)

riskmatrixAVI2<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/GISfiles/May17RiskMatrixV3_SubrCM_AlpacAVI.below600K.csv", header=TRUE)

riskmatrixAVI3<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/GISfiles/May17RiskMatrixV3_SubrCM_noFMA.csv", header=TRUE)

riskmatrixAVI4<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/GISfiles/RiskMatrixV3attributetableSubregion0.csv", header=TRUE)

riskmatrixAVI5<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/GISfiles/RiskMatrixV3attributetableSubregionABandM.csv", header=TRUE)

riskmatrixAVI6<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/GISfiles/July11RiskMatrixV3_SubrCM_newANCtoMillar.csv", header=TRUE)

riskmatrixAVI7<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/GISfiles/July11RiskMatrixV3_SubrCM_newTolkoHighPrairieAndFootner.csv", header=TRUE)

riskmatrixAVI8<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/GISfiles/July11RiskMatrixV3_SubrCM_TolkoVanderwell.csv", header=TRUE)

riskmatrixAVI9<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/GISfiles/July11RiskMatrixV3_SubrCM_VanderwellContractorsFMA.csv", header=TRUE)

riskmatrixAVI10<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/GISfiles/July11RiskMatrixV3_SubrCM_WestFraserAndTolko.csv", header=TRUE)

riskmatrixAVI11<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/GISfiles/July11RiskMatrixV3_SubrCM_WestFraserSlaveLakeFMA.csv", header=TRUE)

riskmatrixAVI12<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/GISfiles/July11RiskMatrixV3_SubrCM_WeyerhauserGrandePrairie.csv", header=TRUE)

riskmatrixAVI13<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/GISfiles/July11RiskMatrixV3_SubrCM_WeyerhauserPembinaTimberland.csv", header=TRUE)

riskmatrixAVI14<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/GISfiles/RiskMatrixV3attributetableSubregionLBHandDM.csv", header=TRUE)

riskmatrixAVI15<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/GISfiles/RiskMatrixV3attributetableSubregionLFabove700K.csv", header=TRUE)

riskmatrixAVI16<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/GISfiles/RiskMatrixV3attributetableSubregionLFbelow700K.csv", header=TRUE)

riskmatrixAVI17<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/GISfiles/RiskMatrixV3attributetableSubregionNandU.csv", header=TRUE)

#now combine the separate tables into one
riskmatrixAVI.A<-rbind(riskmatrixAVI1, riskmatrixAVI2, riskmatrixAVI3,
                       riskmatrixAVI4, riskmatrixAVI5, riskmatrixAVI6,
                       riskmatrixAVI7, riskmatrixAVI8, riskmatrixAVI9,
                       riskmatrixAVI10, riskmatrixAVI11, riskmatrixAVI12,
                       riskmatrixAVI13, riskmatrixAVI14, riskmatrixAVI15,
                       riskmatrixAVI16, riskmatrixAVI17)
```

Each data frame above contains the same number of unique observations as rows, indicating no duplicate observations, for example `r nrow(unique(riskmatrixAVI1))` unique observations and `r nrow(riskmatrixAVI1)` rows in riskmatrixAVI1.

Each data frame above includes the same variables, before they are bound together in single frame, for example `r names(riskmatrixAVI1)`

There are `r nrow(riskmatrixAVI.A)` observations in the data frame after combining all CSV files, so the entire risk matrix AVI attribute table has been loaded into R.

## Step 2. Create age classes in R based on age since stand origin

In the risk matrix for Alberta, foresters assign forest stands to age classes that are meaningful for foresters, but are probably meaningful for breeding birds as well.

```{r get-age-classes, echo=FALSE}
riskmatrixAVI.A$AGE_2017<-as.numeric(riskmatrixAVI.A$AGE_2017)
riskmatrixAVI.A$Shape_Area<-as.numeric(riskmatrixAVI.A$Shape_Area)
str(riskmatrixAVI.A)
riskmatrixAVI.A$ageclass<-{ifelse(riskmatrixAVI.A$AGE_2017==9999,"NA",
                            ifelse(riskmatrixAVI.A$AGE_2017 <3,"Age 0-2 Y",
                              ifelse(riskmatrixAVI.A$AGE_2017 <31,"Age 3-30 Y",
                                ifelse(riskmatrixAVI.A$AGE_2017 <61,"Age 31-60 Y",                                
                                  ifelse(riskmatrixAVI.A$AGE_2017 <81,"Age 61-80 Y",
                                    ifelse(riskmatrixAVI.A$AGE_2017 <101,"Age 81-100 Y",
                                      ifelse(riskmatrixAVI.A$AGE_2017 <141,"Age 101-140 Y","Age 141+")))))))
}
```

## Step 3. Summarize cumulative area, ranks, and relative sampling effort to date within each combination of subregion, stand type, age class, and timber productivity rating

We will use the *dplyr* package in R to summarize total area for each potential combination of these 4 factors.

We first create a list of ranks for each ForestID. ForestID is created by concatenating the subregion name, stand name, age class, and timber productivity rating. Note that some polygons assigned to the same ForestID may be assigned different ranks with some ranked from 1 to 6 and others ranked as 0, NA, or 999.

```{r summarize-area-and-create-ranks-list, echo=FALSE}
library(dplyr)
riskmatrixAVI.A$subregion.name<-riskmatrixAVI.A$NaturalSub
riskmatrixAVI.A$standtype.name<-riskmatrixAVI.A$StandType
riskmatrixAVI.A$tpr.name<-riskmatrixAVI.A$TPR

riskmatrixAVI.A$ForestID<-paste0(riskmatrixAVI.A$subregion.name,".",riskmatrixAVI.A$standtype.name,".",riskmatrixAVI.A$ageclass,".",riskmatrixAVI.A$tpr.name)
#NEW SECTION (September, 2018)
#ranks and area summarized by ForestID
AlbertaForID_Ranks_final_long<-riskmatrixAVI.A%>%
  group_by(ForestID,Rating)%>%
  summarize(ForestArea=sum(Shape_Area)/10000)
AlbertaForID_Ranks_final_long$ForestArea[is.na(AlbertaForID_Ranks_final_long$ForestArea)]<-0 #replace NAs
write.csv(AlbertaForID_Ranks_final_long, file="rawData/AlbertaForID_Ranks_final_long.csv")
#Calculates cumulative area in risk matrix AVI geodatabase within each combination of subregion, stand, age class, and TPR, and ForestID ranking.
```

In the next part, we use the *dplyr* package to summarize the cumulative area of each ForestID separately from ranks, get the point count data, and calculate the number of point counts within a particular ForestID, along with relative sampling effort per ForestID. This is our *gap analysis*.

This data is currently in wide format.

I manually converted it to long format in *areabyForestID* prior to adding bird data back in the May and July versions of the gap analysis.

Now add the bird data.

```{r add-bird-data, echo=FALSE}
#Recast by ForestID
pointcountsformatrix<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/pointsCdatacheckMay23.csv", header=TRUE)
pointcountsformatrix$ForestID<-paste0(pointcountsformatrix$subregion.name,".",pointcountsformatrix$standtype.name,".",pointcountsformatrix$ageclass,".",pointcountsformatrix$tpr.name)
pointsbyForestID<-tapply(pointcountsformatrix$counter, pointcountsformatrix$ForestID, sum)
write.csv(pointsbyForestID, file = "C.samplingGapAnalysis/pointsbyForestID.csv")
#Used Data to Columns in Excel to split ForestID back into separate columns.
#matched up column categories from separate files in Excel, using the values in "pointsbyForestID"

pointsbyForestID<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/pointsbyForestID.csv", header=TRUE)
pointsbyForestID$ForestID<-pointsbyForestID$X
pointsbyForestID$X<-NULL
pointsbyForestID$Count<-pointsbyForestID$x
pointsbyForestID$x<-NULL
areabyForestID<-read.csv("C.samplingGapAnalysis/areabyForestID.csv", header=TRUE)
AlbertaMastermatrix<-merge(pointsbyForestID, areabyForestID, by=c("ForestID"), all=TRUE)
AlbertaMastermatrix$Area.1000units<-AlbertaMastermatrix$Area/1000
AlbertaMastermatrix$SurveyEffort<-AlbertaMastermatrix$Count/AlbertaMastermatrix$Area.1000units
AlbertaMastermatrix$SurveyEffort[is.na(AlbertaMastermatrix$SurveyEffort)]<-0
write.csv(AlbertaMastermatrix, file="C.samplingGapAnalysis/GapAnalysisSurveyEffortPerForestID.csv")
```

For subregions other than CentralMixedwood (which was missing polygons in the combined R data frames back in May), total point counts per combination of subregion, stand, age class, and TPR are the same as those summed back in May.

At this point Area.1000 (area in 1000-ha units) and survey effort can be calculated then the resulting file *GapAnalysisSurveyEffortPerForestID* can be added to the risk matrix AVI in ArcGIS via a spatial join, using ForestID to link survey effort to the attribute table. The data can be reformatted separately in Excel to make the risk matrix survey effort Excel file with coloured cells, to go with the gap analysis report.

## Step 4. Add survey effort to the risk matrix AVI attribute table in ArcGIS to create one-pagers and maps of survey effort.

Once survey effort has been added to the risk matrix AVI attribute table, it will be possible to select data according to survey effort and draw maps identifying regions where more point count data needs to be collected. These maps can be sent to individual companies as one-pagers describing particular Forest Management Units. Shapefiles extracted from the risk matrix AVI but now containing survey effort for particular ForestIDs can be sent to forestry companies that have contributed to FORSITE's risk matrix via FRIAA. Examples of such one-pagers could be linked to this Markdown document eventually, but only with permission from the forestry companies.

## Step 5. Creating the Alberta Master Matrix

The file that was used to create the gap analysis report and which was linked to the risk matrix AVI in ArcGIS can also provide us with a master matrix for Alberta, to be linked to the actual individual point counts rather than just the summarized point count totals per ForestID.

The mastermatrix will be saved to an RData file and cleaned up prior to using it to analyze patterns in the ranks per ForestID and densities of birds per ForestID

```{r create-Alberta-mastermatrix, echo=FALSE}
write.csv(AlbertaMastermatrix, file="RDataFiles/AlbertaMastermatrix.csv")
save(AlbertaMastermatrix, file="RDataFiles/AlbertaMastermatrix.RData")
```
